figure:
\begin{figure}[ht!]
\centering \epsfysize=9cm
\includegraphics[scale=0.7]{fig1.eps}
\caption{\small The dynamics corresponds to the  
particle motion under a  potential with zero energy. We depict the
shape of the potential here. We are interested in the trajectory in which 
the particle starts from infinity, reflected at $f_{min}$ and goes back
to infinity.} 
\

\begin{figure}[ht!]
\centering \epsfysize=9cm
\includegraphics[scale=0.7]{rangec0_final.eps}
\caption{\small The range of the coordinate $\mu$ as a functions of 
$c_0$, where $c_0$ varies from $0$ to $c_{crit}= {9\over 4\sqrt{2}}$, 
$\mu_0$ starts from 
$\mu_0={\pi\over 2}$ and diverges at $c_0=c_{crit}$ } 
\

\begin{figure}[ht!]
\centering \epsfysize=9cm
\includegraphics[scale=0.7]{dil_final.eps}
\caption{\small 
The dilaton  $\phi$  as a functions of $\mu$, for values of $c_0= 
0.2,\; .8, \; 1.3$}
\

\begin{figure}[ht!]
\centering \epsfysize=9cm
\includegraphics[scale=0.7]{fig2.eps}
\caption{\small The conformal mapping of the constant time slice 
 is depicted here. Only the surface 
of the globe described by the $\mu$ and $\lambda$ 
coordinates is relevant here. 
Each point on the surface corresponds to $S^2$. 
The boundary indicated by bold lines corresponds to $S^3$.}
\

\begin{figure}[ht!]
\centering \epsfysize=9cm
\includegraphics[scale=0.7]{fig3.eps}
\caption{\small The conformal diagram of the spatial section
of our solutions is depicted here for the Poincare type coordinate. 
Each point on the plane corresponds to ${ R}^2$.
The coordinate $\mu$ is the polar angle and $y$ is the radial coordinate
with $W$ as the origin.   
The total boundary consists of two parts, each of which has the geometry of
a half of ${R}^3$.  These two parts are joined through $W$, which may be 
viewed as a kind of  domain wall on the boundary. } 
\
